The Federal Reserve used to be known as a secretive place, its officials mysteriously managing the country's monetary policy.

But in recent weeks the chairman of the Fed, Ben Bernanke, has appeared on the weekly news show ""60 Minutes""; he's fielded questions at the National Press Club; he's talking about regular press conferences.
To find out more, we turn to David Wessel.
He's economics editor of the Wall Street Journal, and he's writing a book about the Fed.
And thanks for joining us, David.
Good morning, Renee.
You know, the Fed, as I've indicated, seems to be changing its ways.
Is it?
Yes, absolutely.
It's a slow process.
It began, actually, in 1994.
Before then, the Fed did not announce even when it moved interest rates.
You had to sort of be an insider to figure out they were doing that.
Former chairman Alan Greenspan made the Fed a little more transparent, as they say.

But Ben Bernanke is really taking it much farther, not only being more open about their forecasts about the economy, but as you point out, talking more on the record to the press and going beyond just reaching bond traders and financial journalists, but doing something as popular as ""60 Minutes.
And why has he been doing this?
I think there are two institutional reasons.

One is, he believes that we're in an unusually complicated time in the economy and that people are confused, and that the policies will be more effective and he'll have more political support for them if he can just explain them to people, the way he used to teach freshman economics at Princeton University.
But the other reason is that the Fed has been under a lot of criticism for not being open about what it's doing, for allowing bonuses to be paid at AIG.

And he knows that once the winds start blowing against the institution, that you're on the defensive, and so this is kind of a PR offensive to make the Fed look a little more responsible, a little more open, and a little more reasonable - to the people and the politicians.
But you wonder if the Fed has become less independent from politicians, which it has traditionally been, because of this current financial crisis.
I mean, it sure seems to be working very closely with the White House in formulating financial policy.
Well, that's right.
It's a very delicate balance here.

As a society, we have decided that we need the Federal Reserve to be independent when it comes to setting interest rates and controlling the supply of money to resist inflation, because the conventional wisdom now is that in a democracy, politicians are too prone to let inflation get out of hand.
So we want an independent central bank to handle that.
But we're in the middle of a financial crisis.
We had the Great Depression because the central bank and the White House didn't work well together.
But keeping those two things separate is extraordinarily difficult.
We've gotten to know Ben Bernanke better over these last few months.
What does the change, this new openness, mean for him, given that his term as chairman is up not very long from now, January 2010?

Well, Mr. Bernanke will not admit it, and he won't be explicit about it, but of course the more he looks like a calm, steady hand, a man of the people who is doing the best he can to save the nation's economy from disaster, the more popular he is, and the more likely President Obama will decide to reappoint him when his term is up in the end of January.
And the Fed itself, is it likely to come out of this crisis with more power or less power?

In some respects it's likely to have more power because there's a lot of talk about needing to designate one agency to be the overarching financial stability regulator, the one who is watching to make sure that we're not having insurance companies go into derivatives and causing problems like AIG, or that we're not lending too much money on subprime mortgages to people who can't pay them back.
And the most likely candidate for that is the Fed, and that's a very powerful role.
David Wessel is economics editor of the Wall Street Journal.
